properties.name: Maracas Beach
properties.description:
Maracas Beach is the most well-known beach in Trinidad. It is popular for swimming, body surfing, sun bathing, and camping.
Rip currents are usually present, as marked by red flags by the lifeguards. Take great care with children. It is home to the world-famous shark and bake There are beach chairs for rent, but don't feel like you can't move the unused chairs aroudn to make your own space on the beach. The beach facilities were recently upgraded, with construction ongoing. There is a car park located south of the North Coast Road. Change rooms with showers and toilets are available for a fee. A hotel is also located at the western end of the bay.

properties.name: Macqueripe Bay
properties.description:
Macqueripe Bay is accessed by a flight of stairs from the car park. It is popular for snorkelling and SCUBA diving.

Zip lining at the top

properties.name: Tyrico Beach
properties.description: Adjacent to Maracas Bay, cars park directly on the beach.

properties.name: Las Cuevas Beach
properties.description: The only Blue Flag rated beach on the island. Features caves.

properties.name: L'Anse Martin
properties.description: Swimming and surfing are popular activities/ Wading pools are fun at low tide

properties.name: Blanchisseuse Bay
properties.description:
The mouth of the Marianne River

Parking is available by that one guy.

properties.name: Paria Beach
properties.description: A stack formation is located within an arch on the western end of the beach. The Paria waterfall is a fifteen minute walk inland from the beach. The Paria river enters the sea at the eastern end of the beach.

properties.name: Grand Tacarib Beach
properties.description: Grand Tacarib Beach, often shortened to Gran Tac, is a long beach, accessible only by hiking of by boat.

properties.name: Madamas Beach
properties.description: Madamas is possibly the most secluded beach in the country. The Madamas river empties towards the eastern end of the beach.

properties.name: Matelot Bay
properties.description:
The Eastern End of the Paria Main Road. The beach is small and unsheltered, and so the water is rough and not ideal for swimming. Turtles nest on this beach and seamoss is collected for sale.

The Matelot River enters the bay at the western end is more suitable for swimming.

properties.name: Grande Riviere Bay
properties.description:
Grande Riviere is a world famous beach for viewing nesting sea turtles. Permits are required from the Forestry Division, and tour guides can be be arranged from the Visitor Information Center.

Bathing is unsafe. The Grand Riviere River enters the sea at the eastern end of the bay.

properties.name: Sans Souci Bay
properties.description: Surfing is done here during the high wave energy months of ? and the waves are consistent enough for the hosting of a regional surf competition.

properties.name: Salybia Bay
properties.description: Salybia Bay is on the extreme northeastern tip of Trinidad.

properties.name: Balandra Bay
properties.description: Coconut palms, buttonwood, almond, noni and other coastal vegetation line the beach. the Balandra River enters the sea in the middle section of the bay.  Swimming, snorkeling, and SCUBA diving are popular activities. Vehicles can park along the Balandra Bay Road. There is a fishing facility at the northern end of the beach where freshwater is available.

properties.name: Saline Bay
properties.description:
Unfortunately, this beach is commonly confused by 'Salybia Bay', including by the person who is writing this. We can't all be experts. Saline Bay is located south of Balandra Bay and is also commonly known as 'Sally Bay'. The water is generally clear and clam, but swimmers must be cautious where the river meets the sea. 

The coastal plain behind the beach is used as a car park, for camping and for picnics. Kayaks are available for rent to explore up the river. There is a daily lifeguard service, and the there are change rooms and toilets available for a fee. A fishing facility is located on the western side of the river.

properties.name: Matura Bay
properties.description:
Matura Bay is an important leatherback turtle-nesting site. The sea is rough with rip currents, and so is unsafe for swimming. 

At Orosco Road there is a visitor center with a toilet and a rest area adjacent to the car park.

properties.name: Cocos (Manzanilla) Bay
properties.description: Amenities include a car park, toilets, change rooms, a snack bar, and picnic tables. The coconut plantations on the low lying land behind Cocos Bay provide a scenic background. Beyond the coconuts there is a freshwater Nariva Swamp, a designated wetland of international importance under the Ramsar convention.

properties.name: Mayaro Beach
properties.description: Mayaro is one of the main fishing centers of the country.

properties.name: Guayaguayare Bay
properties.description:
Guayaguayare Bay is located at the south-eastern corner of Trinidad. 

The beach is fringed with coconut palms and two rivers flow across it. THe Lizard River enters the northeastern end of the bay, and the Lawai River flows in the western end. A seawall stretches along the coast near the Lizard River, behind which there is a popular restaurant and bar A fishing depot is located east of the seawall. 

The preferred place for swimming is in the center of the bay.

properties.name: Gran  Chemin Beach
properties.description:
The beach is bounded by two headlands. The water is turbid and brown for much of the year, especially during the rainy season, as a result of the Orinoco River discharge into the Columbus channel. 

The beach is the main recreation ground for the residents and there is a small fishing center.

properties.name: Quinam Bay
properties.description: Quinam Bay is the most attractive and well known beach on the south coast. The Quinam river flows across the central portion of the beach. There is a recreation park with features a visitors center, BBQ pits, huts and tables. Several nature trails have been established through the woods. A car park and toilet facilities are located near the beach, and there is a daily lifeguard service.

properties.name: Los Iros Bay
properties.description: The bay is ideal for swimming and there is a daily lifeguard service. Caution should be exercised at the eastern end where longshore and rip currents are strongest. It is windsurfing and kite boarding hotspot. A privately owned beach facility has a car park, huts, picnic tables , and restrooms for a fee.

properties.name: South Chatham Beach
properties.description: South Chatham Beach is ideal for swimming and fishing. However, the beach is seculded and visitors should be aware of their surroundings at all times.

properties.name: Columbus Bay
properties.description: Good for swimming but sandflies can ruin the fun. An unpaved car park si located at the end of the road. A beach facility with a picnic area and toilets is available for a fee

properties.name: Bonasse Beach
properties.description: The sea tends to be calm for most of the year and the currents are weak. There are no beach facilities for visitors here. The beach is poplar with locals for fishing and recreation. There is a fishing facility and small shops line the road.

properties.name: Granville Beach
properties.description: Swimming and camping are popular activities on this beach, but swimmers should be cautious as there is no lifeguard service. A small river exits at the eastern end of the bay.

properties.name: Guapo Beach
properties.description: The Guapo beach facilities includes a spacious car park, food court, swimming pool change rooms and toilets. The backshore is vegetated mangrove and grassland and has a lagoon

properties.name: Vessigny Beach
properties.description: The beach is a favorite with local residents, and there is a daily lifeguard service. The landscaped grounds and well-maintained facilities include a car park, snack bar, camping grounds, and change rooms with showers and toilets.

properties.name: Williams Bay
properties.description: Williams Bay is usually shallow and during spring low tides, one can alk for over 100m on the soft muddy floor of the intertidal zone. Non-swimmers and children are comfortable bathing here.

properties.name: Chagville Beach
properties.description: Now blocked by Five Islands Amusement Park. It certainly is amusing to watch our country head down the wrong paths.

properties.name: Scotland Bay
properties.description: Only accessible via boats. The destination of many a party boat
